Genius and learning tho' we gain,</br>Genius and learning bless in vain;</br>How shared with error and with woe,</br>The progress of my tale would shew,</br>Till application call'd them forth,</br>And virtue gives its labours worth.

A pair of heavenly origin,</br>O'er empire once were born to shine;</br>The king received from Jove's high hand,</br>His skill profound, his just command;</br>And from a ray of ether's flame,</br>The queen deriv'd her dazzling frame.</br>One child they had alone to bless,</br>With hopes of an extended race.</br>To hail the stranger's dawning hours,</br>Assembled all the gifted powers:</br>As rank prescrib'd they now resort,</br>And first, Carmenta paid her court.</br>I come, she said, oh!  most rever'd,</br>Accept the offering, I've prepar'd;</br>The brilliant presents others give</br>From mine shall higher worth receive.</br>Behold!  this phial's limpid juice, </br>In every scene of sovereign use.
From the pure lily's virgin breast,</br>I charm'd the chrystal dew,</br>The beam which first Aurora drest,</br>As faithfully I drew.
With these a zephyr's breath infus'd,</br>Then pierc'd the briny wave;</br>And thence this beauteous pearl produc'd,</br>From Ocean's richest cave.
While thus to form and more refine,</br>I heavenly fire impell'd,</br>Within my essence I confine,</br>Hermetically seal'd.
This essence still from chance secure,</br>No time or use shall waste;</br>And prayers shall best extract it pure,</br>And leave its fountain chaste.
As other graces issue forth,</br>To raise the prince's name,</br>My gift conveys them richer worth,</br>And yields them pure to fame.

The next the prince's birth had drawn,</br>To hail with gifts his early dawn;</br>Advanced with step of easy grace,</br>And half unveil'd her lovely face;</br>While beauteous flowers adorn'd her head,</br>A sun was on her breast display'd.</br>A cabinet and key she bore,</br>And thus set forth her offer'd store:</br>While freely all the gifted train,</br>Adorn your offspring, bless your reign.</br>My works which have for ages been,</br>And yet, alas!  but dimly seen,</br>And careless view'd by common sight,</br>My works, this key displays to light:</br>And if applied with skilful hand,</br>By these five doors my stores command.</br>This door unfolded, charms the sight,</br>From this the powers of sound delight.</br>Here Flora has her perfumes drest.</br>And here Pomona meets the taste.</br>But ah!  the fifth essay with care,</br>Angels, or fiends inhabit there.</br>From this my works their worth receive:</br>Here it expires, or here shall live.</br>Here lives offence!  here high reward!</br>Carmenta's phial is your guard!
The next an endless scroll had brought.</br>The next a vase with wonder wrought,</br>Form'd to receive and to produce,</br>Amazing stores to instant use.

These gifts insured the royal pair.</br>A joy disdaining fear to share;</br>They scarcely call'd in Hope to see,</br>The honours of their progeny.</br>E'en now around his infant frame,</br>The beams of future glory flame;</br>Yet of the fates they wish'd to know,</br>The happy future sanction'd now.</br>Sanguine, they strike their magic rod,</br>To draw them from their dark abode;</br>Where far removed from mortal ken,</br>Decrees of gods they write for men:</br>Their brazen pens, their juices lave,</br>From Cocytus's inky wave;</br>And straight th' irrevocable word,</br>On adamantine leaves record.</br>With wond'rous skill the distaff's wound,</br>And soon the wheel of life goes round;</br>The sheers suspend, the thread is spun,</br>Tis cut — and mortal life is done.</br>The royal pair these prayers repeat,</br>To draw them from their awful seat;</br>Dread sisters of the rosy hours,</br>Daughters of Jove!  relentless powers!</br>Who write with an eternal pen,</br>The firm decree of gods on men,</br>Sisters three, enrob'd in white,</br>Appear, and sanction our delight.</br>Ascend, and from your dark abodes,</br>Shew us the bright decrees of Gods:</br>And lo!  dark clouds obscure the light,</br>With semblance premature of night.</br>Tempest succeeds the Zephyr's breeze,</br>And troubled waves to glassy seas:</br>Confusion thunders thro' the skies,</br>And stern the destinies arise.</br>Earth cleaves, and, at their near approach,</br>Fair Order shudders from their touch.

Tell us, they cry, why we must rise,</br>To trouble earth and vex the skies;</br>While we by partial all are staid,</br>The work of worlds remains delay'd;</br>Summon'd by you we yet are come,</br>Then hear our words, for they are doom;</br>The Prince, from many potent pow'rs,</br>Has brilliant gifts to gild his hours;</br>But all is vain they might display,</br>If shorten'd life forbid their stay;</br>And ah!  his wheel of life appears</br>Inclin'd to stop at eighteen years;</br>But ere our work decisive prove.</br>Still we must join in hate and love;</br>If firm the thread of life shall keep,</br>The wheel may stop, death is but sleep,</br>And even from that sleep to free,</br>Admits of possibility;</br>But circumstance will so obtain,</br>That scarce a ray from hope we gain,</br>One hint observe and well receive,</br>(All alas that we can give;)</br>Virtuous pursuits wait glorious ends,</br>And much depends on choice of friends.
Hastening th' attendant shades away,</br>This said, they quit the glare of day;</br>Ghastly they smiled, their torch they fir'd,</br>And with the jar of elements retir'd.

For shades, shines Phoebus' radiant beam,</br>And what the niggard fates scarce deem,</br>As possible to human skill,</br>Hope enters ready to fulfil.</br>A thousand schemes their minds prepare,</br>Sanguine in each to shun the snare.

Their orders issue thro' the land,</br>And all the wise before them stand;</br>The mystic presents to explain,</br>That nought might be bestow'd in vain;</br>These give Carmenta's gift it's force,</br>And shew religion virtue's source:</br>All other means prove insecure,</br>To leave it safe and draw it pure.

The Cabinet they next explore,</br>Of various charms, a wondrous store;</br>From the first door to vision rise,</br>What natures curious hand supplies;</br>Expanding all the wond'ring sense,</br>To beauty and benevolence;</br>And here — the masters skill'd to teach,</br>Explain what human pow'rs can reach.</br>The fine gradations far they see,</br>Till lost in vast infinity.</br>Immense, till distance shades their light,</br>Minute, they lessen from the sight;</br>The second door unfolds to cheer</br>With pleasing sounds th' enraptur'd ear;</br>Here intercourse, its bliss receives,</br>And heav'nly conversation lives;</br>Nor here the master's skill is less,</br>The force of language to impress;</br>Than wake the sounds that touch the heart,</br>And all their pow'r to charm impart.</br>The two succeeding doors display,</br>What lib'ral nature can convey.</br>Our pleasures with our wants can sort,</br>And lure us to our own support;</br>And ever faithful to her rights,</br>From harm repels, to good incites.</br>The masters shew the prudent care,</br>That ought these bounteous gifts to share;</br>And punishment she will exert,</br>O'er those who waste or who pervert.

The skilful masters next unroll</br>The windings of the awful scroll,</br>And teach, tho' earth her dust will claim,</br>Deeds shall retain their place in fame,</br>And actions, vicious or sublime,</br>Shall live accurs'd, or blest, thro' time.

Next, the internal world they view,</br>And there their pupils' wonder drew,</br>And more minutely to explore,</br>Open the last, th' important door;</br>It they approach with sacred awe,</br>And first Carmenta's phial draw,</br>Whose sacred essence can refine,</br>All mortal gift by aid divine;</br>Then, straight they touch those springs to wake,</br>From which all deeds their merit take,</br>Above cold maxims, there they shew,</br>The generous act exalted glow;</br>Here precept takes its force to warm,</br>And virtues wear a living charm;</br>For faint assent, here faith has given,</br>To ardent hope her absent heaven;</br>For forms here warm devotions rise,</br>To wrest the blessing from the skies;</br>Here justice melts at mercy's charms,</br>And guilt by penitence disarms;</br>For tardy alms cold duties guide,</br>Here nameless charities reside;</br>Here tenderest sympathies are found,</br>And nature seals her firmest bond;</br>By these, impell'd to deeds of fame,</br>The hero spreads his awful name,</br>The sacred guardians of the land,</br>'Tis here that patriot minds expand;</br>Where human laws are weak to bind,</br>Here sense of honour leads the mind,</br>'Tis Liberty, 'tis nature's school,</br>Where virtue's unconfin'd to rule;</br>And here arise those arts with grace,</br>Which learning is so proud to dress;</br>Beyond the critic line she draws,</br>Here warm imagination glows;</br>Her rules may harmony impart,</br>Here rise the sounds that warm the heart.

Sweet poetry!  the charms are thine,</br>That here the sister arts combine;</br>And here deserve thy triple wreathe,</br>Where music speaks, and paintings breathe;</br>And let th' according chaplet be,</br>Inscrib'd to heav'nly harmony;</br>For Liberty and Nature's school,</br>Teach graces unattain'd by rule.

The prince was quickly skill'd to reach,</br>Th' extent of all that art could teach</br>To each he gave a master's claim,</br>And for a trophy sign'd his name;</br>And soon their easy task was o'er,</br>For Learning could inform no more.

The parents, with exulting strains,</br>Declare a friend alone remains;</br>And early there their care shall be,</br>And well observ'd their far decree,</br>That all who can adorn a court,</br>From earth's far peopl'd climes resort,</br>That for their son with high reward,</br>They choose a friend his youth to guard;</br>The oracle they thus pursu'd,</br>And hop'd their evil fate subdu'd,</br>Among the first resorting there,</br>Two equally divide their care;</br>Tutor'd by fashion and by art,</br>One won the queen's consenting heart;</br>The other, veil'd by modesty,</br>Yet gain'd the king's approving eye;</br>The first, with self-assuring mein,</br>Gaily approach'd the brilliant queen;</br>No diffidence her claims prevent,</br>No aukward fears produced restraint;</br>By art, with lilies vied her neck,</br>And borrow'd roses stain'd her cheek,</br>With soften'd voice, and studied smiles,</br>She thus the easy queen beguiles—

You spoke your wishes, charming queen,</br>And lo!  th' accomplish'd world are seen.</br>So with the first my claims are brought,</br>And more than all, with justice fraught;</br>The hours of joy bright queen are mine,</br>And I with youth and beauty shine;</br>No drudging labour can oppress,</br>Whenever I am call'd to bless;</br>Perhaps your Lord, by means severe,</br>Will try to shun the fate you fear;</br>With joy repelling eye will blast,</br>The time of pleasure youth should taste.</br>If there thou yield, thy son with grief,</br>Will court his fate as wish'd relief;</br>Steady, a kindred pow'r defend,</br>In me fair queen protect a friend.

Her polish'd grace the queen approv'd,</br>And thought a kindred pow'r she lov'd,</br>One that could fortune's gifts employ,</br>To brighten every hour with joy.</br>Vainly the king she would ensnare,</br>For him, her words dissolv'd in air;</br>His modest suppliant he view'd,</br>Who silent yet before him stood;</br>An hour-glass in her hand she bore,</br>An amaranth in her hair she wore;</br>But doubtful by her dress display'd,</br>Its folds were form'd of light and shade;</br>She stood thus dubious in her worth,</br>Waiting till Judgment call'd her forth;</br>Nor, till a favouring look she caught,</br>Own'd the pretensions she had brought;</br>And then in words of simple frame,</br>She thus advanc'd her modest claim—

I have no brilliant parts to boast,</br>Nor was I train'd with art or cost;</br>I seldom with the gay am seen,</br>The great dislike my humble mien;</br>But those who have me most carest;</br>Will say I grateful am at least;</br>And own thro' me it was they shone,</br>And tell of wonders I have done;</br>By you directed, mighty lord,</br>Wonders again they shall record;</br>No lazy spell infests the ground,</br>Where I am lov'd and I am found;</br>If your protection I may ask,</br>To guard from evil be my task.

Friendship unchang'd resides above,</br>And there alone dwells equal love;</br>While other blessings strew our road,</br>Faith points to these as promis'd good;</br>E'en wedlock may this evil share,</br>And Wit and Judgment sometimes jar.</br>Our monarchs, tho' of heav'nly birth,</br>Must here partake the lot of earth;</br>Their different tastes opinion guides,</br>An interest dear their heart divides;</br>Their counsels each themselves obey,</br>And leave disputes to vulgar clay.

Invested with supreme command,</br>Which open force could ne'er withstand,</br>The king with public honours grac'd,</br>And near his son his favorite plac'd;</br>To her confided all his stores,</br>And named her guardian of his hours.

The queen these counsels did not share,</br>And opposition would not dare;</br>In wiles she trusted for her cause,</br>To render vain the monarch's laws;</br>To give persuasion to her tongue,</br>She tun'd her favorite's syren song;</br>If flattering praise could not secure,</br>She dazzling interest gave to lure;</br>Luxuriant charms around her spread,</br>With her own roses crown'd her head,</br>And all seducing to command,</br>With honour's palms she grac'd her hand;</br>In each some lurking spell there lay,</br>Potent to charm and to betray;</br>The first alluring as she draws,</br>She baited with the world's applause;</br>Then specious as the theme she sung,</br>The syren song flow'd from her tongue;</br>Virtue she sung a cheating dream;</br>High sounding honours were her theme;</br>She sung, that names thro' time rever'd,</br>Thro' toils and death had madly err'd;</br>Her grateful palms she then display'd,</br>A meed for favorites fortune made;</br>These too enchanting snares she spread,</br>Her soft temptations artful laid,</br>To draw the Prince to leave the bound,</br>Which judgment fix'd to safety's ground,</br>No orisons now pierce the skies,</br>For aught Carmenta's gift supplies;</br>Its gay exterior all its merit,</br>Its form alone without its spirit.

And now the pride of all his store,</br>The prince but as a bauble wore;</br>A trinket, taking reputation,</br>As pearls of price were gems of fashion;</br>And led by that capricious guide,</br>Thrown by the changing mode aside.

Often the prince now pass'd the bound,</br>His father gave to safety's ground;</br>Lost to the pow'r which should defend,</br>His guardian is no more a friend;</br>Nor doubtful longer she appears,</br>All sable is the robe she wears.
'Twere endless here to name the train,</br>That took from hence a mortal stain;</br>Grant them the boon, forgot to lie,</br>Remember'd, it were infamy.

Needful supply for luxury's food,</br>The charms of interest next subdu'd;</br>The hoards of avarice stood display'd,</br>Gaily the golden stores were spread:</br>There cheerless nature sunk in gloom,</br>'Twas virtue and affection's tomb;</br>There nought of value now remains,</br>In aught the cabinet contains;</br>For sordid interest's transient claim,</br>He sold the glories of his name.

Oh avarice!  were thy deeds forgot,</br>'Twould save humanity a blot;</br>Peru nor Mexico should tell,</br>India or Africa reveal;</br>Hide in the silence of the grave;</br>Passions which nature never gave.</br>The injurer and the injur'd sleep,</br>Let memory then no vigils keep;</br>Oblivion!  their foul deeds receive,</br>But ah!  condemn'd by fame they live;</br>History unsparing tells thro' time,</br>The savage wonders of their crime.

By pleasure's fascinating pow'r,</br>The rosy garland next he wore;</br>No more he visits safety's ground,</br>No guardian for his hours is found;</br>His mother's favorite takes the reins.</br>And binds him in her pleasing chains;</br>Silky and soft, and ting'd with gold,</br>But there was magic in their mold;</br>Than adamantine bonds more strong,</br>To hold the hapless captive long;</br>Their pow'r resistless they impart,</br>The mind to crush and bind the heart;</br>Furies that into storms awake,</br>For influence dread dominion take;</br>Chaos of elemental strife!</br>Here work your tragedies of life.

If to that fatal scene she lead,</br>I would not with my favorite tread;</br>Let darkness veil its kindred scene,</br>Unseen the horrors wrought within;</br>Dread gulfs are hid in fairy bowers,</br>And poisons lurk in beauteous flowers;</br>Who near their precincts dare to stray,</br>Contagions meet, or wild dismay.</br>There nothing curious be my choice,</br>To shun the daring forms of vice;</br>But some unaw'd your haunts shall view,</br>And mark that vengeance dwells with you;</br>With gifts most meet for actions foul,</br>Her worms of conscience for the soul;</br>If error's labyrinth I must show,</br>Thro' scenes less guilty let me go;</br>Not interest fell, nor vain applause,</br>Nor where tempestuous passion draws,</br>But rather where the drowsy sense,</br>Is lull'd by pamper'd indolence;</br>There sunk in unaspiring ease,</br>I mourn my favorite lost, to please;</br>No good or ill incites his powers,</br>Lost to the guardian of his hours;</br>He festive wreathes alone desires,</br>Whose magic, damps his nobler fires;</br>Their sweets his senses all compose,</br>While music its soft aid bestows;</br>The goblet fair and downy couch,</br>Thus with his threaten'd fate approach;</br>Languid — scarce moves life's lazy thread,</br>It ceases now, the wheel is staid,</br>Unbroken firm, the thread to keep,</br>The wheel is stay'd, and death is sleep.

Reclin'd upon an ebon throne,</br>The drowzy god whom poppies crown,</br>Receives him in his silent shade,</br>With hanging juniper o'erspread;</br>The lizard and the dormouse there,</br>Forget the rigour of the year;</br>Around them lulling vapours rise,</br>From incense, mortals' sacrifice,</br>Attracting vapours to renew,</br>The cowslip and the mandrake's dew</br>Clouds wrought in twilight's doubtful doom,</br>Inclose the borders of the gloom;</br>Nor moon's calm beam, nor sun's bright ray,</br>There draw the herald of the day;</br>But oft the beetle wheels around,</br>And there the moping owl is found.
The royal pair here weeping turn,</br>And past divisions deeply mourn;</br>They own the justice of their fate,</br>And mercy thus they supplicate—

As error and distress are ours,</br>Be pardon yours Almighty powers;</br>And while our humble prayers we pour,</br>And all your Providence adore,</br>If past offence  we may repair,</br>To our repentance, oh!  declare!
Mercy remitting sorrow's date,</br>Thus answers by relenting fate—

For crimes be true repentance yours,</br>And for repentance pardon ours.</br>Tho' won by penitential tears,</br>She melts the sternness which he wears;</br>Mercy thus potent to subdue,</br>Were weak not join'd by justice too;</br>Attend the mandate of the skies,</br>So may your humbled hopes arise;</br>For you bright queen to heaven allied,</br>Be duty to your Lord your guide;</br>Where those would lead who should obey,</br>Disorders rule for equal sway;</br>You sire who boast celestial birth,</br>Jove's mighty attribute on earth,</br>'Tis yours to clear the misty way,</br>And lead your son to life and day;</br>Directed by your mighty powers,</br>Recall the guardian of his hours:</br>To execute th' important scheme,</br>Her labor lightly she shall deem;</br>Tis yours to seal her doubtful worth,</br>And well instructed send her forth;</br>For ere the wheel of life goes round,</br>Some worthy offering must be found.

He ceas'd, and well his words imprest,</br>An ardour in the monarch's breast;</br>His hasten'd step he instant bent,</br>To trace the path his favorite went;</br>He saw her on a rock reclin'd,</br>Where persevering ivy twin'd; </br>And as an hour-glass now she turn'd,</br>Its wasting sands she deeply mourn'd.</br>Soon as the king appear'd in view,</br>Her garments lost their sable hue:</br>For as the shades dispell'd by light,</br>The black dissolv'd in spotless white.</br>Soon as the king her eye had caught,</br>A sprig of amaranth she brought; </br>And wav'd it with triumphant air,</br>And plac'd it in her flowing hair;</br>Whilst prostrate at his feet she fell.</br>Her artless words her raptures tell;</br>Prostrate she says — hail mighty Lord!</br>By you neglected I have err'd,</br>Oh guide me that I may restore,</br>The Prince whose loss we all deplore;</br>The creeping ivy climbs to height,</br>And insects lofty trees invite.</br>Deeds impossible to thought,</br>Are by application wrought;</br>By you directed mighty Lord,</br>Wonders again they shall record.

Her worth neglected touch'd his heart,</br>Relenting thoughts these words impart.</br>Thy pardon give and mine receive,</br>Cherish'd by me in future live;</br>Me to decree the gods inspire,</br>Thee they endow with active fire;</br>With winged feet then speed thy skill</br>To gain the summit of the hill.</br>Twelve sisters, sent on high import,</br>(The shining nymphs of Phoebus' court;)</br>Move in swift succession there,</br>Swift as they move, oh!  watch with care;</br>Ardent the aid of each implore,</br>For ah!  they will return no more.

The monarch ceas'd, and while the sound</br>Yet vibrates in the air around,</br>She flew with more than mortal speed,</br>Over the intervening mead.</br>And soon she gains th' important hill,</br>Chosen her trials to fulfil;</br>No more, she says, my weaken'd sense</br>Is lull'd by charms of indolence,</br>Nor driv'n by guilt to misery;</br>Yet worse than useless shall I be,</br>For judgment now decides my worth,</br>And leads me to call genius forth.

Essaying then the rising ground,</br>Twelve nymphs of heav'nly form she found;</br>And fair they were, of heav'nly show,</br>And locks of gold stray'd o'er their brow.</br>Their locks of gold, they wav'd in air,</br>And tears bedew'd their faces fair;</br>With varied hues each garment shines,</br>Their girdles shew'd the circling signs;</br>And short their dress, and fleet their course,</br>Not stay'd by courtesy or force.</br>Oh nymphs divine!  our heroine cry'd;</br>That heed me not but onward glide,</br>To mortals sure your errands be,</br>And each some treasure has for rue.

Mortal attend, they quick return'd,</br>For not unsought our gifts are earn'd:</br>Let every trifling thought give place,</br>And strive to conquer, in thy race.</br>They said, and bid the fair pursue,</br>In swift succession as they flew,</br>Then Application quick pursued;</br>Temptations nobly she subdued;</br>Tho' indolence her downy bed,</br>And pleasure, flaunting roses spread.—

The steady nymph disdainful ey'd</br>Their tempting sweets, and thus replied,</br>I see the stings thro' pleasure's snare,</br>And quick she pass'd each heavenly fair.</br>With wonder working influence fraught,</br>Some fair occasion still she caught,</br>From the wing'd speed of HOURS to take,</br>Spells that Genius might awake;</br>With some the path of glory treads,</br>And there collects his shining deeds;</br>While some Carmenta's gift supplies,</br>With song to charm the destinies;</br>From some she takes and learns to wield,</br>Virtue's secure protecting shield.

Thus, arm'd to conquer, on she sped,</br>By Virtue guarded, Judgment led;</br>She soon the dusky borders found,</br>Where Genius in soft chains was bound;</br>And soon her burnish'd shield she shew'd,</br>Quick thro' the gloom its radiance glow'd;</br>The gloom receiv'd its influence bright,</br>And shade dissolv'd in radiant light;</br>She pure Carmenta's phial draws;</br>On high the meek petition rose;</br>And to appease the destinies,</br>To Genius all its aids supplies;</br>To softest notes she tun'd her tongue,</br>And thus she sung Carmenta's song:
Ye nymphs of Pluto's dark domain</br>Receive your drowzy God;</br>With gifts from Phoebus' brilliant train,</br>I visit this abode.
If man, by selfish passion sway'd,</br>Can pity, hear and spare;</br>With power and mercy Gods array'd,</br>Accept an ardent prayer.
Warm from the heart these words shall rise,</br>That must conclude my song;</br>The Gods will own the sacrifice,</br>And their own gifts prolong.
Your gifts shall ever speak your praise,</br>Bright attributes of power,</br>And the rich bounties of your grace</br>To your own glory soar.
Wake Prince, she said, I call thee forth,</br>Decided is my dubious worth;</br>My labours with thy presence crown,</br>Labours that would be all thy own.
Thy energy must spread the use,</br>Of this fair phial's limpid juice;</br>My labours with thy presence crown,</br>Labours that would be all thy own.
Fancy would droop without thy aid,</br>And all its op'ning flowers would fade;</br>If fates are sooth'd, to thee belong</br>The notes that raise the heavenly song.
Let deeds of glory thee inspire;</br>Without thee, deeds of fame expire;</br>He rose, his presence nature warms,</br>For him extended all her charms.

He cull'd her gaily op'ning flowers,</br>And with them dress'd his beauteous bowers:</br>'Twas he inspir'd the poet's dream,</br>On northern hills, by Mulla's stream;</br>Or where the, silver waters glide,</br>Of Thames's deep majestic tide.

When Spencer wrote and Sidney smil'd,</br>And generous friendship care beguil'd;</br>Time them on Avon's banks receives,</br>And amaranthine wreathes he gives;</br>There fairies frisk beneath the moon,</br>In darkness witching spells are done.</br>He touch'd with skill the awful band,</br>And charmed there the Passions stand.

He tun'd to harmony his tongue,</br>And thro' the seasons Thomson sung.</br>Scenes the sublimest thought could find,</br>He open'd to a Milton's mind;</br>And oft by contemplation led,</br>With pensive Grey he sought the shade;</br>Thro' many an age and many a clime,</br>These flourish thro' enduring time;</br>He drew the phial's purest store,</br>And gave to it a living pow'r;</br>Thence shone the patriot and the sage,</br>Examples for the moral page;</br>Those with its lustre fame supplies,</br>The rest, perennials of the skies;</br>Such worth may still Britannia boast,</br>Tho' she has mourn'd her Howard lost;</br>Whate'er the favour'd spot of earth</br>That gave exalted merit birth;</br>And, as its different lots were cast,</br>In milder graces it surpass'd;</br>Or shone with aspect more severe,</br>Still worth shall kindred worth revere.

Immortal laurels to entwine,</br>Virtue with Genius must combine;</br>And Application's active aid</br>Perform the plan by Judgment laid;</br>Recorded wonders they can shew,</br>And means of glorious heights bestow;</br>They different natures nearly join,</br>And human make almost divine.
For these to save, thro' wrecks of time belong,</br>Th' historians faithful page, the muses' heavenly song.</br>
